Topic.Title: YHOO price target was raised at Needham to $26

Message.Msg: First Goldman raises Yahoo's PT to $24, now Needham takes Yahoo to $26. The Alibaba Group IPO will send Yahoo to $30. That coldone guy was right. Who were those idiots arguing with coldone?

Topic.Title: YHOO price target was raised at Needham to $26

Message.Msg: Needham has been bullish on Yahoo (YHOO) shares the past several years amid the value of its Asian holdings. However, until the past several months, the market hasn't shared the investment bank's enthusiasm. But as the stock has jumped 1/3 since the end of August and to the brink of $20 for the first time since the financial crisis, Needham boosts its price target to $26 from $19. It puts the value of Yahoo Japan and Alibaba at $15/YHOO share and YHOO's P/E at 3.3, resulting in an "attractive" risk-reward ratio. And with the company having said it plans to buy some $3.6B of stock, or 9 days of trading volume, Needham points to AOL, whose stock has surged in 2H amid divestment-funded buybacks

Message.Title: Habermansham & Co.
Message.Msg: "We find little improvement in Yahoo's financial performance that would cause us to recommend the stock to our clients. Our clients are encouraged to avoid the stock as we find the downside risk to be greater than the upside potential. We continue to believe that the financial engineering that is occurring will not drive any sustainable stock price increase and that to reverse years of revenue declines Yahoo will / must invest at a much higher rate in new product offerings than they have in the last half decade or so. The simple tweaking of Yahoo that has occurred so far does not demonstrate to us anything beyond putting new paint and curtains on house in a community of foreclosure. We encourage our clients invested in Yahoo to take profits before year end and that clients without a position in Yahoo should not establish positions."

Topic.Title: YHOO price target was raised at Needham to $26

Message.Msg: That was the weakest upgrade ever. They didn't say a single positive thing about the company. Didn't say revenue would grow or that earnings would increase. Nothing about new business or new products, nothign about strength in the existing suite, or increases in customer base. The only thing they said was that the buyback would artificially increase share price by reducing the float. Really? That's what you're all excited about? Good luck with that. I live the way that the analyst with a $26 price target is a genious, but the analyst with a $16.50 price target is conveniently ignored or dismissed - yeah, whatever supports your existing believe.
